pullRequest.body:
`image_subset_iff` is a questionable simp lemma because it converts an application of `Set.image` into an application of `Set.preimage` unconditionally. This means that if any simp lemma applies to images, there must be a corresponding lemma for preimages. These lemmas are what I found missing after loogling.

I also added machine-checked examples of each confluence issue to a new file `tests/simp_confluence`.

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]
-->

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body: I don't believe there is an analogous confluence issue for `Finset` because [`Finset.image_subset_iff_subset_preimage`](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Data/Finset/Preimage.html#Finset.image_subset_iff_subset_preimage) is not marked `@[simp]`
🚀 Pull request has been placed on the maintainer queue by YaelDillies.

Pull request successfully merged into master.

  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/7870398122/job/21471492489)

maintainer merge

Looks good to me, thanks!

bors r+

I am now convinced this is a good change.

Would you mind checking that the analogous situations for `Finset` are confluent?
maintainer merge

Looks good to me, thanks!

bors r+

I don't think those three docstrings are good docstrings. I think they should be regular comments. This information is all about the `simp` attribute and this is not what users want to see as documentation.

Rather than saying there's a confluence issue, could you mention concretely what the confluence issue is? In particular, it would be helpful to see a term that simplifies in two ways depending on the order the theorems are applied, and also what these terms both get simplified into given this new simp theorem.

I added machine-checked examples of the confluence issue and moved the docstrings to document the examples instead of the theorems, which seems more appropriate. I don't think there's precedent for this kind of confluence regression test in the middle of a file, but this seemed like a better option than adding just a more explicit comment since now if these lemmas become unnecessary we'll find out.
You shouldn't put tests/examples in mathlib files, put them in `tests/` if needed.

Okay. I moved them to `tests/simp_confluence.lean`. Now there is no comment on these lemmas, which might be fine. I figure if someone is wondering about what their purpose is, one of the first things they will do is "Go to references" which will turn up these tests.

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion · simp [h, -image_preimage_eq, -preimage_subset_preimage] · simp [h, -image_subset_iff, -preimage_subset_preimage] ```

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion · simp [hs, -Nonempty.image_const, -Nonempty.subset_preimage_const] · simp [hs, -image_subset_iff, -Nonempty.subset_preimage_const] ```

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion · simp [-image_univ, -univ_subset_preimage] · simp [-image_subset_iff, -univ_subset_preimage] ```

```suggestion
theorem univ_subset_preimage {f : α → β} {s} : univ ⊆ f ⁻¹' s ↔ range f ⊆ s := by
```
I think you should make `univ_subset_iff` simp instead
I would still need a simp lemma `f ⁻¹' s = univ ↔ range f ⊆ s` as well, right? Would you suggest replacing this lemma with one about `= univ` and making `univ_subset_iff` simp?
Yes, exactly. I believe we independently want `f ⁻¹' s = univ ↔ range f ⊆ s` as a simp lemma anyway.

```suggestion
theorem preimage_subset_preimage {f : α → β} {s t : Set β} (h : Surjective f) :
```
What if you make `preimage_subset_preimage_iff` simp instead of adding a new lemma?

That requires another `@[simp]` lemma to prove the precondition of `preimage_subset_preimage_iff`. Is it advisable to have `simp` be responsible for a chain of reasoning `f.surjective` -> `s ⊆range f` -> `f ⁻¹' s ⊆ f ⁻¹' t ↔ s ⊆ t` like this? I don't know how brittle simp's precondition search is

```lean
@[simp]
theorem Set.subset_range_of_surjective {f : α → β} (h : Surjective f) (s : Set β) :
    s ⊆ range f := Surjective.range_eq h ▸ subset_univ s
```

[Playground](https://live.lean-lang.org/#code=import%20Mathlib.Data.Set.Image%0Aimport%20Mathlib.Tactic%0A%0Aopen%20Set%20Function%0A%0Aattribute%20%5Bsimp%5D%20preimage_subset_preimage_iff%0A%0A%40%5Bsimp%5D%0Atheorem%20Set.subset_range_of_surjective%20%7Bf%20%3A%20%CE%B1%20%E2%86%92%20%CE%B2%7D%20(h%20%3A%20Surjective%20f)%20(s%20%3A%20Set%20%CE%B2)%20%3A%0A%20%20%20%20s%20%E2%8A%86%20range%20f%20%3A%3D%20Surjective.range_eq%20h%20%E2%96%B8%20subset_univ%20s%0A%0Aexample%20%7Bf%20%3A%20%CE%B1%20%E2%86%92%20%CE%B2%7D%20(s%20t%20%3A%20Set%20%CE%B2)%20(h%20%3A%20Surjective%20f)%20%3A%0A%20%20%20%20f%20''%20(f%20%E2%81%BB%C2%B9'%20s)%20%E2%8A%86%20t%20%E2%86%94%20f%20''%20(f%20%E2%81%BB%C2%B9'%20s)%20%E2%8A%86%20t%20%3A%3D%20by%0A%20%20conv%20%3D%3E%0A%20%20%20%20congr%0A%20%20%20%20%C2%B7%20simp%20%5Bh%2C%20-image_preimage_eq%5D%0A%20%20%20%20%C2%B7%20simp%20%5Bh%2C%20-image_subset_iff%5D%0A)
I think this lemma is worth having because `s ⊆ range f` preconditions are pretty common.

```suggestion
```
Would you mind adding the corresponding lemma for `Finset`?
Done
